2.text: Pathogenic bacteria in the body cause infections,

6.text: which can be treated by antibiotics

23.text:
Bacteriostatic antibiotics slow the growth
of bacteria by interfering with the processes the bacteria need to multiply

68.text: for example by preventing the bacteria from making a cell wall

94.text: Antibiotics can be so-called broad spectrum, affecting many different bacteria in your body

101.text: including useful bacteria in your gut.

107.text: Some antibiotics are more narrow spectrum,

109.text: only affecting one or two types of bacteria

113.text: It is better to use narrow spectrum antibiotics where possible

118.text: Most antibiotics have no effect on your immune system

125.text:
Antibiotics do not work on viruses because
viruses have a different structure to bacteria

132.text:
Viruses incorporate themselves into a host
cell in your body in order to multiply.

138.text: Bacteriostatic antibiotics that affect bacterial DNA,

143.text: metabolism or protein production do not attack body cells

147.text: and therefore do not slow the growth of viruses

152.text: Viruses do not have a cell wall and therefore bactericidal antibiotics that act on cell walls cannot kill viruses
